Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Manifestations of Cooper Pairing and Decoherence in Elementary Qubits
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This CAREER award supports fundamental theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics on the nanoscale and on quantum coherence control. Research will be focused on (i) nonequilibrium superfluidity beyond the adiabatic regime, (ii) corruption of quantum states in nanoscale solid-state devices, and (iii) superconducting pairing near the superconductor-insulator transition. The PI aims to develop reliable theories of these phenomena and to verify them by detailed quantitative comparison with experiments.

The focus of the research component includes:
. systematic identification of the strengths and limitations of existing qubit designs,
. developing the fundamentals of the theory of decoherence due to interaction with spin-like environments,
. developing a microscopic theory of superconductivity near the superconductor-insulator transition, which explains and predicts a range of unusual phenomena in disordered superconductors,
. Developing a comprehensive theory of non-stationary Cooper pairing beyond the adiabatic regime.

The study of superfluidity and superconductivity, and nanoscale physics provides excellent educational and outreach opportunities. The PI plans to develop a graduate course on mesoscopic and nanoscale physics and an outreach program: "The Promise of Physics on the Nanoscale." The outreach program, designed in collaboration with the PI's colleagues in science pedagogy, aims to nurture an appreciation of modern nanophysics in secondary school and undergraduate classrooms with a view towards creating a more scientifically literate general public.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This CAREER award supports fundamental theoretical research and education in condensed matter physics on the nanoscale and quantum coherenece control. One focus of this work lies in the study of how particular quantum mechanical states can be created and manipulated. The states themselves occur in nanoscale superconductors, trapped ultracold atoms, and strongly correlated electron materials, and their nature is of fundamental scientific interest in their own right. This effort focuses, in part, on understanding such states, which open potential technological gateways, for example, new paradigms in computing. Another focus of this work is to advance understanding of the physical mechanisms that can defeat a device that exploits the manipulation of quantum mechanical states for its operation. The PI will focus on states made from electron spins, which are regarded as among the most promising for quantum computation in solid-state materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in the following key fundamental developments: (i) comprehensive theory of far from equilibrium superconductivity (ii) prediction and understanding of new states of superfluid matter (iii) explanation of a novel insulating state observed in disordered superconductors (iv) theoretical discovery of new phenomena in coherent many-body dynamics, such as supersolitons and superfluid turbulence (v) new theory of quantum integrable systems (vi) better understanding of topological states of matter.

In a series of publications we put forward and advanced a theory of far from equilibrium superconductivity, which has been a challenging fundamental problem dating back several decades. Our theory describes the dynamics of superconductors and superfluids in response to sudden external perturbations. In particular, it predicts nonequilibrium states (phases) the superconductor goes to after the perturbation ends. For example, for moderate perturbations the quantity that characterizes superconducting correlations (order parameter) oscillates to a constant that can be several times different from its equilibrium value. A distinctive feature of this dynamics is that the oscillation frequency is twice the constant. This prediction has been verified by an experimental group lead by Prof. Shimano in Japan. Another state we predicted is a new kind of gapless nonequilibrium superfluid that combines properties of normal and superfluid states.

We were among the first to quantitatively describe the phases of multicomponent superfluids made up of more than two fermion species. Conventional superfluids consist of two such species and have only one superfluid component.  

We showed that the novel insulating state seen experimentally in disordered superconductors is a result of an intricate interplay between superconducting interaction (effective attraction between electrons) and the fractal features of electron wavefunctions that emerge as disorder increases.

What happens when an isolated quantum phase of matter is subject to a sudden uniform perturbation? Most previous studies assumed spatially uniform evolution. However, the stability of the homogeneous state with respect to the spontaneous eruption of spatial non-uniformity is by no means guaranteed due to interactions and the extensive quantity of energy injected into the system. Indeed, we showed that e.g. in one-dimensional systems such perturbations can induce strong inhomogeneity and give rise to non-dispersive density waves that exhibit a rigid shape, with amplitudes that grow in time as a power law (“supersolitons”).

A similar phenomenon occurs in three-dimensional superfluids where sudden uniform perturbations result under certain circumstances in a turbulent growth of spatial modulations and eventually in a state characterized by a random superposition of wave packets of the superfluid order.

Quantum integrability is when a quantum system has special additional symmetries. This property has a range of profound consequences, such as degeneracies, non-thermal behavior etc. Such systems have received a great deal of attention in recent years, since some of them have been realized in atomic, nanoscale and macroscopic many-body physics. However, in contrast to classical mechanics, the very notion of integrability in quantum mechanics is under debate. The main difficulty is that it is difficult to separate trivial symmetries that are always present from nontrivial ones characteristic of quantum integrability. We proposed a simple, constructive notion of quantum integrability that resolved this difficulty. Moreover, our proposal resulted in several important developments, such as construction and solution of new quantum integrable models, their classification, explanation of degeneracies etc.
